questions.text: A key project is coming up that you know well. How do you approach it?

options.text: I handle most of it myself ‚Äî it's faster and I know it'll be done right
I assign tasks but check in constantly to make sure nothing goes off track
I brief someone capable on the outcome I need and schedule a mid-point check-in
I hand it to the best person, agree on milestones, and let them own the approach entirely

questions.text: One of your team members delivers work that's 'good enough' but not how you'd do it. What happens next?

options.text: I redo it myself ‚Äî the quality needs to match my standard
I give detailed corrections and ask them to redo it my way
If it meets the objective, I accept it and note the style difference for future coaching
I acknowledge their approach, discuss what 'great' looks like, and trust them to improve over time

low.title: The Bottleneck
low.description: You're likely doing too much yourself. Your team can't grow if you hold onto everything, and you're burning out in the process. This is the most common trap for talented managers.
tips: Pick one recurring task you do weekly and fully delegate it this week ‚Äî resist the urge to take it back
Ask yourself: 'Am I the only person who can do this?' If not, delegate it
Accept that 80% done by someone else is better than 100% done by you at the cost of your strategic time

mid.title: The Hoverer
mid.description: You delegate tasks but struggle to let go of control. Your team gets assignments but also gets the feeling you don't fully trust them. This limits their ownership and growth.
tips: Set clear outcomes upfront instead of prescribing the method ‚Äî focus on the 'what', not the 'how'
Replace constant check-ins with agreed milestones ‚Äî let them come to you
When you feel the urge to jump in, write down your concern instead and discuss it at the next scheduled check-in

high.title: The Multiplier
high.description: You understand that delegation is about developing people, not just offloading tasks. You trust your team with ownership and focus your energy on strategy and coaching.
tips: Continue raising the bar ‚Äî delegate more complex, strategic work to stretch your top performers
Document your delegation framework so other managers on your team can replicate it
Identify your next successor for key responsibilities to build deeper bench strength

questions.text: How do your 1-on-1 meetings with direct reports typically go?

options.text: I don't really do regular 1-on-1s ‚Äî we talk when something comes up
We meet occasionally, but it's mostly me giving updates or assigning work
We meet regularly with a loose agenda ‚Äî a mix of status updates and personal check-ins
We meet weekly with a shared agenda they own ‚Äî focused on their growth, blockers, and priorities

questions.text: A usually strong team member seems disengaged lately. What do you do?

options.text: I wait and see if it resolves itself ‚Äî I don't want to pry
I mention it casually in passing and hope they open up
I bring it up directly in our next 1-on-1 and ask how they're doing
I create a safe space in our 1-on-1 to explore what's changed ‚Äî listening first, then problem-solving together

low.title: Flying Blind
low.description: Without regular 1-on-1s, you're missing critical signals from your team. Problems fester, people feel unseen, and you'll be surprised by resignations and performance issues.
tips: Block 30 minutes weekly with each direct report starting this week ‚Äî make it non-negotiable
Start simple: ask 'What's going well? What's blocking you? How can I help?'
Make the meeting about them, not you ‚Äî resist the urge to use it as a status update

mid.title: Surface Level
mid.description: You meet with your team but aren't getting the full value from 1-on-1s. The conversations stay safe and transactional. There's an opportunity to build much deeper trust and insight.
tips: Let your direct report set the agenda ‚Äî send a shared doc 24 hours before and let them fill it first
Spend at least half the meeting on their development, not task updates
Ask better questions: 'What would you do differently if you were in my role?' or 'What's one thing I could do to better support you?'

high.title: Connected Leader
high.description: Your 1-on-1s are a real leadership tool. You build trust, surface issues early, and invest in your people's growth. This is what separates good managers from great ones.
tips: Challenge yourself to have one 'courageous conversation' per month that pushes both of you to grow
Track themes across your 1-on-1s ‚Äî patterns reveal systemic issues worth addressing
Share your own challenges and growth areas to model vulnerability and deepen trust

questions.text: It's Monday morning. How does your week typically start?

options.text: I jump straight into emails and Slack ‚Äî the day runs me
I have a rough idea of priorities but get pulled into reactive work by noon
I review my top 3 priorities and block time for them, but I sometimes let meetings creep in
I've pre-planned my week ‚Äî my top priorities have protected time blocks, and I've already said no to non-essential meetings

questions.text: Your calendar is full but a senior leader asks you to take on an 'urgent' project. What do you do?

options.text: I say yes immediately and figure out how to squeeze it in ‚Äî I can't say no to leadership
I say yes but quietly stress about how I'll get everything done
I ask what the deadline is and try to negotiate the timing to fit my schedule
I share my current priorities and ask them to help me decide what to deprioritize to make room

low.title: The Firefighter
low.description: You're constantly reacting instead of leading. Your days are consumed by other people's priorities, and your most important work keeps getting pushed to 'someday'. This is unsustainable.
tips: Identify your top 3 priorities each week and schedule them as meetings with yourself ‚Äî treat them as non-negotiable
Audit your calendar: cancel or delegate any recurring meeting where you're not essential
Practice saying 'Let me check my priorities and get back to you' instead of automatic yes

mid.title: The Juggler
mid.description: You know what matters but struggle to protect your time for it. You start with good intentions but get pulled off course. The gap between your plan and your reality is where your impact leaks.
tips: Use time-blocking: schedule your most important work during your peak energy hours and guard those blocks fiercely
Create a 'not-doing' list ‚Äî things you're intentionally saying no to this quarter
Batch reactive work (email, Slack) into 2-3 windows per day instead of constant monitoring

high.title: The Strategist
high.description: You control your time instead of letting it control you. You're intentional about where you spend energy and comfortable pushing back on demands that don't align with your priorities.
tips: Teach your team your prioritization framework so they can self-serve instead of escalating
Schedule quarterly 'strategic thinking' blocks ‚Äî unstructured time for your biggest challenges
Regularly audit: are your time investments aligned with your highest-leverage activities?

questions.text: You need to fill a role on your team. How do you approach hiring?

options.text: I post the job and hope for good candidates ‚Äî hiring is mostly luck
I write a job description based on the last person's role and interview whoever HR sends me
I define the key outcomes for the role, create structured interviews, and evaluate candidates against those criteria
I'm always building a pipeline ‚Äî I know what roles I'll need, network proactively, and have a rigorous process that tests for both skills and values fit

questions.text: You realize a team member is consistently underperforming. How do you handle it?

options.text: I avoid the conversation ‚Äî it's uncomfortable and maybe they'll improve on their own
I hint at the issues and hope they pick up on it, or wait for the annual review
I have a direct conversation about the gap, set clear expectations, and give them a defined period to improve
I address it early with specifics, co-create an improvement plan, provide support ‚Äî but also prepare to make a change if needed

low.title: Reactive Recruiter
low.description: Hiring feels like an emergency every time a role opens, and underperformers linger too long. Both drain your team's energy and results. The cost of a bad hire ‚Äî or a slow fire ‚Äî is massive.
tips: Before posting any role, write down the 3 outcomes this person must deliver in their first 6 months
Create a simple scorecard for interviews so you evaluate all candidates against the same criteria
For underperformers: have the conversation this week. Waiting never makes it easier

mid.title: Process Builder
mid.description: You have some hiring structure but it's inconsistent. You address performance issues eventually, but often later than you should. Tightening both processes will dramatically improve your team quality.
tips: Implement a structured interview process: consistent questions, scoring rubric, multiple interviewers
Address performance gaps within 2 weeks of noticing them ‚Äî not 2 months
After every hire, do a 90-day retrospective: did the process predict their actual performance?

high.title: Talent Architect
high.description: You treat team composition as a strategic advantage. You hire deliberately, manage performance proactively, and aren't afraid to make tough calls for the good of the team.
tips: Build a talent map: who are your flight risks, who needs development, who's ready for promotion?
Create a referral engine ‚Äî your best hires come from your team's networks
Develop a 'manager training' program so your strong performers can step into leadership

questions.text: A team member made a mistake on a client deliverable. How do you handle it?

options.text: I fix it myself and don't mention it ‚Äî I don't want to create conflict
I send a message about quality standards to the whole team ‚Äî without calling anyone out specifically
I talk to them directly, explain what went wrong, and discuss how to prevent it next time
I address it promptly and privately, ask for their perspective first, then collaborate on a specific plan to improve the process

questions.text: When was the last time you gave someone positive recognition for their work?

options.text: I can't remember ‚Äî if they're doing their job, that's what they're paid for
I say 'good job' occasionally but don't get specific
I try to acknowledge good work regularly and tie it to the impact it had
I have a habit of recognizing contributions publicly and privately, being specific about what they did and why it mattered

low.title: The Silent Manager
low.description: Your team is operating without a feedback loop. They don't know where they stand, what 'great' looks like, or whether their work matters. This kills motivation and growth.
tips: Give one piece of specific positive feedback and one piece of constructive feedback this week
Use the SBI model: Situation, Behavior, Impact ‚Äî it removes emotion and keeps feedback factual
Remember: avoiding feedback isn't kindness, it's avoidance. Your team deserves to know where they stand

mid.title: The Broadcaster
mid.description: You communicate but without enough precision or consistency. Your feedback might be too vague to be actionable, or you give it too infrequently for it to drive change.
tips: Make feedback immediate: address things within 24 hours while context is fresh
Be specific: replace 'great job' with 'the way you handled that client objection was excellent because...'
Schedule a monthly 'feedback pulse' where you proactively share observations on each team member's growth

high.title: The Coach
high.description: You create a culture where feedback flows naturally in both directions. People on your team know exactly where they stand and feel safe bringing issues to you.
tips: Ask for upward feedback regularly: 'What's one thing I could do differently as your manager?'
Help your team give feedback to each other ‚Äî build a culture, not just a personal practice
Document growth conversations so you can show people their progress over time

questions.text: How does your team know what they should be focused on this quarter?

options.text: They mostly figure it out themselves based on what comes in ‚Äî I trust them to know their job
I share company goals and hope they connect the dots to their own work
We set team goals together at the start of each quarter and review them occasionally
Each person has clear, measurable goals tied to team objectives ‚Äî we review progress weekly and adjust as needed

questions.text: A team member consistently misses deadlines but does good work when they deliver. What do you do?

options.text: I just adjust timelines in my head ‚Äî their work is good, so I work around it
I express frustration when it happens but don't follow up with a structured conversation
I have a conversation about the pattern and ask what's causing it
I address the pattern directly, help them identify root causes, set specific commitments, and follow up consistently until the habit changes

low.title: The Hope Manager
low.description: You're managing by hope instead of by design. Without clear goals and accountability, your team drifts, priorities conflict, and results become unpredictable.
tips: Set 3-5 measurable goals for your team this quarter ‚Äî make them visible and specific
Create a simple weekly check-in ritual: 'What did you commit to? What did you deliver? What's next?'
Remember: accountability isn't micromanagement. People actually want clarity about what success looks like

mid.title: The Goal Setter
mid.description: You set goals but struggle with the follow-through. Goals get set at the start of the quarter and reviewed at the end ‚Äî with a gap in between where accountability fades.
tips: Make goals visible: put them on a shared dashboard or document that the team sees weekly
Hold a 15-minute weekly stand-up focused solely on progress against key goals
When someone misses a commitment, address it immediately ‚Äî not at the end of the quarter

high.title: The Accountability Partner
high.description: You combine clear expectations with consistent follow-through. Your team knows what matters, how they're tracking, and that commitments mean something.
tips: Evolve from goals to OKRs or a similar framework that connects individual work to company strategy
Empower your team to hold each other accountable ‚Äî not just relying on you
Celebrate progress, not just completion ‚Äî recognize the behaviors that drive results

config.title: Management Diagnostic
config.subtitle: Discover your management strengths and blind spots in 5 minutes
config.ctaText: Want to go deeper? Book a free strategy call
config.emailPlaceholder: We'll send you a copy of your results and actionable resources
